question: Hey, I hear we're gonna be roommates. I'm Neil Perry.
answer: Todd Anderson.

question: Why'd you leave Balincrest?
answer: My brother went here.

question: Hey Knox.
answer: Neil, study group tonight?

question: Yeah, sure.
answer: Business as usual, huh? Hey, I hear you got the new kid. Looks like a stiff! Oops!

question: Okay, study group. Meeks aced Latin. I didn't quite flunk English. So, if you want, we've got our study group.
answer: Sure. Cameron asked me too. Anyone mind including him?

question: Hmm, what's his specialty, boot-licking?
answer: Come on, he's your roommate.

question: Oh yeah, sure. Valedictorian. National merit scholar.
answer: Oh well, welcome to Hell-ton.

question: It's every bit as tough as they say, unless you're a genius like Meeks.
answer: He flatters me. That's why I help him with Latin.

question: Keep your seats fellows, keep your seats. Neil, I've just spoken to Mr. Nolan. I think that you're taking too many extra curricular activities this semester, and I've decided that you should drop the school annual.
answer: But I'm the assistant editor this year.

question: Well I'm sorry Neil.
answer: But Father, I can't. It wouldn't be fair.

question: Don't you ever dispute me in public. Do you understand?
answer: Father, I wasn't disputing-

question: After you've finished medical school and you're on your own, then you can do as you damn well please. But until then, you do as I tell you. Is that clear?
answer: Yes sir. I'm sorry.

question: You know how much this means to your mother, don't you?
answer: Yes sir. You know me, always taking on too much.

question: Well, that's my boy. Now listen, you need anything, you let us know, huh?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Well come on. "Oh Captain, My Captain" who knows where that comes from? Not a clue? It's from a poem by Walt Whitman about Mr. Abraham Lincoln. Now in this class you can call me Mr. Keating. Or, if you're slightly more daring, Oh Captain, My Captain. Now let me dispel a few rumors so they don't fester into facts. Yes, I too attended Hell-ton and survived. And no, at that time I was not the mental giant you see before you. I was the intellectual equivalent of a ninety-eight pound weakling. I would go to the beach and people would kick copies of Byron in my face. Now, Mr Pitts. That's a rather unfortunate name. Mr. Pitts, where are you? Mr. Pitts, would you open your hymnal to page 542 and read the first stanza of the poem you find there?
answer: "To the virgins, to make much of time"?

question: Yes, that's the one. Somewhat appropriate, isn't it.
answer: "Gather ye rosebuds while ye may, old time is still a flying, and this same flower that smiles today, tomorrow will be dying."

question: Thank you Mr. Pitts. "Gather ye rosebuds while ye may." The Latin term for that sentiment is Carpe Diem. Now who knows what that means?
answer: Carpe Diem. That's "seize the day."

question: Very good, Mr.-
answer: Meeks.

question: I'll get it. Can I help you?
answer: Hi. Knox Overstreet. Uh, Dr. Hager.

question: Hi.
answer: This is the Danburry's, right?

question: Are you here to see Chet?
answer: Mrs. Danburry?

question: No.
answer: Yes.

question: How was dinner?
answer: Huh?

question: How was dinner?
answer: Terrible. Awful.

question: Why? What happened?
answer: Tonight, I met the most beautiful girl in my entire life.

question: Rip it out, rip!
answer: What the hell is going on here?

question: I don't hear enough rips.
answer: Mr. Keating.

question: Mr. McAllister.
answer: I'm sorry, I- I didn't know you were here.

question: I am.
answer: Ahh, so you are. Excuse me.

question: Keep ripping gentlemen. This is a battle, a war. And the casualties could be your hearts and souls. Thank you Mr. Dalton. Armies of academics going forward, measuring poetry. No, we will not have that here. No more of Mr. J. Evans Pritchard. Now in my class you will learn to think for yourselves again. You will learn to savor words and language. No matter what anybody tells you, words and ideas can change the world. I see that look in Mr. Pitt's eye, like nineteenth century literature has nothing to do with going to business school or medical school. Right? Maybe. Mr. Hopkins, you may agree with him, thinking "Yes, we should simply study our Mr. Pritchard and learn our rhyme and meter and go quietly about the business of achieving other ambitions." I have a little secret for ya. Huddle up. Huddle up! We don't read and write poetry because it's cute. We read and write poetry because we are members of the human race. And the human race is filled with passion. Medicine, law, business, engineering, these are all noble pursuits, and necessary to sustain life. But poetry, beauty, romance, love, these are what we stay alive for. To quote from Whitman
answer: Quite an interesting class you gave today, Mr. Keating.

question: I'm sorry if I shocked you, Mr. McAllister.
answer: Oh, there's no need to apologize. It was very fascinating, misguided though it was.

question: You think so?
answer: You take a big risk by encouraging them to be artists John. When they realize they're not Rembrandts, Shakespeares or Mozarts, they'll hate you for it.

question: We're not talking artists George, we're talking free thinkers.
answer: Free thinkers at seventeen?

question: Funny, I never pegged you as a cynic.
answer: Not a cynic, a realist. Show me the heart unfettered by foolish dreams, and I'll show you a happy man.

question: But only in their dreams can man be truly free. 'Twas always thus, and always thus will be.
answer: Tennyson?

question: Mr. Keating? Mr. Keating? Sir? Oh Captain, My Captain?
answer: Gentlemen.

question: We were just looking in your old annual.
answer: Oh my God. No, that's not me. Stanley "The Tool" Wilson- God.

question: What was the Dead Poets Society?
answer: I doubt the present administration would look too favorably upon that.

question: Why? What was it?
answer: Gentlemen, can you keep a secret?

question: Sure.
answer: The Dead Poets were dedicated to sucking the marrow out of life. That's a phrase from Thoreau that we'd invoke at the beginning of each meeting. You see we'd gather at the old Indian cave and take turns reading from Thoreau, Whitman, Shelley; the biggies. Even some of our own verse. And in the enchantment of the moment we'd let poetry work its magic.

question: Sounds boring to me.
answer: Don't go.

question: You know how many de-merits we're talking Dalton
answer: So don't come, please.

question: Look, all I'm saying is that we have to be careful, we can't get caught.
answer: No shit, Sherlock.

question: What about you Knox?
answer: I don't know Charlie.

question: Come on Knox, it'll help you get Chris.
answer: Yeah? How?

question: Women swoon.
answer: But why do they swoon? Charlie, tell me why they swoon. Charlie!

question: Todd, are you coming tonight?
answer: No.

question: Why not? God, you were there. You heard Keating. Don't you want to do something about it?
answer: Yes, but-

question: But? But what?
answer: Keating said that everybody took turns reading and I don't want to do that.

question: Gosh, you really have a problem with that, don't you?
answer: N- no, I don't have a problem. Neil, I just- I just don't want to do it, okay?

question: All right. What if you didn't have to read? What if you just came and listened?
answer: That's not how it works.

question: Forget how it works. What if - what if they said it was okay?
answer: What? What are you gonna do, go up and ask them? No. No, Neil.

question: I'll be right back.
answer: Neil, Neil!

question: Arrr, I'm a dead poet.
answer: Aww, Charlie.

question: Guys, over here.
answer: You're funny. You're real funny. It's too wet.

question: God, are you trying to smoke us out of here?
answer: No, no, the smoke's going right up this opening.

question: I've got one that's even better than that.
answer: Ha!

question: I do. There's a young, married couple, and they're driving through the forest at night on a long trip. And they run out of gas, and there's a madman on the-
answer: The thing with the hand-

question: I love that story.
answer: I told you that one.

question: You did not. I got that in camp in sixth grade.
answer: When were you in six, last year?

question: I know. A lot of you looked forward to this about as much as you look forward to root canal work. We're gonna talk about Shakespeare as someone who writes something very interesting. Now, many of you have seen Shakespeare done very much like this:
answer: The students are all seated together near the front of the room as Keating reads from a book.

question: "Dogs, sir? Oh, not just now. I do enjoy a good dog once in a while, sir. You can have yourself a three-course meal from one dog. Start with your canine crudites, go to your Fido flambe for main course and for dessert, a Pekingese parfait. And you can pick your teeth with a little paw."
answer: The students are all back in their normal seats and Keating leaps up onto his desk.

question: I found it.
answer: You found what?

question: What I wanna do right now. What's really, really inside me.
answer: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"?

question: This is it.
answer: What is this?

question: It's a play, dummy.
answer: I know that. I-- Wh-Wh-What does it have to do with you?

question: Right. They're putting it on at Henley Hall. Open tryouts. Open tryouts!
answer: Yes, so?

question: So, I'm gonna act. Yes, yes! I'm gonna be an actor! Ever since I can remember, I've wanted to try this. I even tried to go to summer stock auditions last year, but, of course, my father wouldn't let me. For the first time in my whole life I know what I wanna do. and for the first time I'm gonna do it whether my father wants me to or not! Carpe diem!
answer: Neil, Neil, hold on a minute. How are you gonna be in a play if your father won't let you?

question: First I gotta get the part, then I can worry about that.
answer: Yeah, but won't he kill you if he finds out you went to an audition and didn't even tell him?

question: No, no, no, no. As far as I'm concerned, he won't have to know about any of this.
answer: Well, that's impossible.

question: Bullshit! Nothing's impossible.
answer: Well, why don't you just call him and ask him? And m-maybe he'll say yes.

question: That's a laugh! If I don't ask him, at least I won't be disobeying him.
answer: Yeah, but if he said--

question: Jesus, Todd! Whose side are you on? I mean, I haven't even gotten the part yet. Can't I even enjoy the idea for a little while? You're coming to the meeting this afternoon?
answer: I don't know. Maybe.

question: Nothing Mr. Keating has to say means shit to you, does it, Todd?
answer: W-What is that supposed to mean?

question: You're in the club! Being in the club means being stirred up by things. You look about as stirred up as a cesspool.
answer: So- You want me out?

question: No! I want you in, but being in means you gotta do something. Not just say you're in.
answer: Well, listen, Neil. I-I appreciate this concern, but I-I'm not like you. All right? You, you, you say thing and people listen. I'm, I'm not like that.

question: Don't you think you could be?
answer: No! I--I, I don't know, but that's not the point. The, the, the point is that there's nothing you can do about it, so you can just butt out. I can take care of myself just fine. All right?

question: No.
answer: What do you mean, "no"?

question: No.
answer: Give me-- Neil. Neil, give that back.

question: Now, devotees may argue that one sport or game is inherently better than another. For me, sport is actually a chance for us to have other human beings push us to excel. I want you all to come over here and take a slip of paper and line up single file. Mr. Meeks, time to inherit the earth. Mr. Pitts, rise above your name. I want you to hand these out to the boys, one apiece. You know what to do, Pitts.
answer: "Oh to struggle against great odds. To meet enemies undaunted."

question: Sounds to me like you're daunted. Say it again like you're undaunted.
answer: "Oh to struggle against great odds. To meet enemies undaunted."

question: Okay, okay, okay, okay.
answer: Neil, how are you gonna do this?

question: They need a letter of permission from my father and Mr. Nolan.
answer: You're not gonna write it.

question: Oh yes, I am.
answer: Oh, Neil. Neil, you're crazy.

question: No, no. It's not stupid. It's a good effort. It touched on one of the major themes, love. A major theme not only in poetry, but life. Mr. Hopkins, you were laughing. You're up. Congratulations, Mr. Hopkins. Yours is the first poem to ever have a negative score on the Pritchard scale. We're not laughing at you, we're laughing near you. I don't mind that your poem had a simple theme. Sometimes the most beautiful poetry can be about simple things, like a cat, or a flower or rain. You see, poetry can come from anything with the stuff of revelation in it. Just don't let your poems be ordinary. Now, who's next? Mr. Anderson, I see you sitting there in agony. Come on, Todd, step up. Let's put you out of your misery.
answer: I, I didn't do it. I didn't write a poem.

question: Mr. Anderson thinks that everything inside of him is worthless and embarrassing. Isn't that right, Todd? Isn't that your worst fear? Well, I think you're wrong. I think you have something inside of you that is worth a great deal. "I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world." W. W. Uncle Walt again. Now, for those of you who don't know, a yawp is a loud cry or yell. Now, Todd, I would like you to give us a demonstration of a barbaric "yawp." Come on. You can't yawp sitting down. Let's go. Come on. Up. You gotta get in "yawping" stance.
answer: A yawp?

question: No, not just a yawp. A barbaric yawp.
answer: Yawp.

question: Come on, louder.
answer: Yawp.

question: No, that's a mouse. Come on. Louder.
answer: Yawp.

question: Oh, good God, boy. Yell like a man!
answer: Yawp!

question: There it is. You see, you have a barbarian in you, after all. Now, you don't get away that easy. The picture of Uncle Walt up there. What does he remind you of? Don't think. Answer. Go on.
answer: A m-m-madman.

question: What kind of madman? Don't think about it. Just answer again.
answer: A c-crazy madman.

question: No, you can do better than that. Free up your mind. Use your imagination. Say the first thing that pops into your head, even if it's total gibberish. Go on, go on.
answer: Uh, uh, a sweaty-toothed madman.

question: Good God, boy, there's a poet in you, after all. There, close your eyes. Close your eyes. Close 'em. Now, describe what you see.
answer: Uh, I-I close my eyes.

question: Yes?
answer: Uh, and this image floats beside me.

question: A sweaty-toothed madman?
answer: A sweaty-toothed madman with a stare that pounds my brain.

question: Oh, that's excellent. Now, give him action. Make him do something.
answer: H-His hands reach out and choke me.

question: That's it. Wonderful. Wonderful.
answer: And, and all the time he's mumbling.

question: What's he mumbling?
answer: M-Mumbling, "Truth. Truth is like, like a blanket that always leaves your feet cold."

question: Forget them, forget them. Stay with the blanket. Tell me about that blanket.
answer: Y-Y-Y-You push it, stretch it, it'll never be enough. You kick at it, beat it, it'll never cover any of us. From the moment we enter crying to the moment we leave dying, it will just cover your face as you wail and cry and scream.

question: Hello?
answer: She's gonna hate me. The Danburrys will hate me. My parents will kill me. All right, goddamn it. You're right. "Carpe diem." Even if it kills me.

question: Hello?
answer: Hello, Chris?

question: Yes.
answer: Hi. This is Knox Overstreet.

question: Oh, yes. Knox. Glad you called.
answer: She's glad I called.

question: Listen, Chet's parents are going out of town this weekend, so he's having a party. Would you like to come?
answer: Would I like to come to a party?

question: Friday? Um-
answer: Well, sure.

question: About seven?
answer: Okay, great. I-I'll be there, Chris.

question: Okay.
answer: Friday night at the Danburrys'. O-Okay. Thank you.

question: Okay. Bye.
answer: Thank you. I'll see you. Bye. Yawp! Can you believe it? She was gonna call me. She invited me to a party with her.

question: Thank you. I'll see you. Bye. Yawp! Can you believe it? She was gonna call me. She invited me to a party with her.
answer: At Chet Danburry's house.

question: Yeah.
answer: Well?

question: So?
answer: So, you don't really think she means you're going with her?

question: Well, of course not, Charlie. But that's not the point. That's not the point at all.
answer: What is the point?

question: The point, Charlie, is, uh--
answer: Yeah?

question: No grades at stake, gentlemen. Just take a stroll. There it is. I don't know, but I've been told--
answer: I don't know, but I've been told--

question: Doing poetry is old--
answer: Doing poetry is old--

question: Todd? Hey.
answer: Hey.

question: What's going on?
answer: Nothing. Today's my birthday.

question: Is today your birthday? Happy birthday.
answer: Thanks.

question: What's you get?
answer: My parents gave me this.

question: Isn't this the same desk set-
answer: Yeah, yeah. They gave me the same thing as last year.

question: Oh.
answer: Oh.

question: Maybe they thought you needed another one.
answer: Maybe they weren't thinking about anything at all. Uh, the funny thing is about this is I, I didn't even like it the first time.

question: Todd, I think you're underestimating the value of this desk set. I mean, who would want a football or a baseball, or-
answer: Or a car.

question: Or a car if they could have a desk set as wonderful as this one? I mean, if, if I were ever going to buy a, a desk set twice, I would probably buy this one both times. In fact, its, its shape is, it's rather aerodynamic, isn't it? I can feel it. This desk set wants to fly. Todd? The world's first unmanned flying desk set.
answer: Oh, my!

question: Hello? Hello, Chris?
answer: Knox!

question: Hi.
answer: You made it. Great! Bring anybody?

question: No.
answer: No. Ginny Danburry's here. Wait. I have to go find Chet. Why don't you go downstairs where everybody is? Make yourself at home.

question: I don't really know Mutt.
answer: To Mighty Mutt.

question: To Mighty Mutt.
answer: Well, listen, I gotta go find Patsy. Say hello to Mutt for me, okay?

question: "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou art more lovely and more temperate."
answer: That's so sweet.

question: I made that up just for you.
answer: You did?

question: Chet, no! You'll hurt him! No! No! Stop it! Leave him alone!
answer: Goddamn!

question: Chet, stop it!
answer: Bastard!

question: Knox, are you all right?
answer: Chris, get the hell away from him!

question: Chet, you hurt him!
answer: Good!

question: Hey, would you not worry about your precious little neck? If they catch me, I'll tell them I made it up.
answer: Sit. In this week of Welton's Honor there appeared a profane and unauthorized article. Rather than spend my valuable time ferreting out the guilty persons -- and let me assure you I will find them - - I'm asking any and all students who knows anything about this article to make themselves known here and now. Whoever the guilty persons are, this is your only chance to avoid expulsion from this school.

question: Welton Academy. Hello. Yes, he is. Just a moment. Mr. Nolan, it's for you. It's God. He says we should have girls at Welton.
answer: Wipe that smirk off your face. If you think, Mr. Dalton, that you're the first to try to get thrown out of this school, think again. Others have had similar notions and have failed just as surely as you will fail. Assume the position. Count aloud, Mr. Dalton.

question: One. Two. Three. Four. Five.
answer: What is this Dead Poets Society? I want names.

question: You kicked out?
answer: No.

question: So what happened?
answer: I'm to turn everybody in, apologize to the school and all will be forgiven.

question: So, what are you gonna do? Charlie!
answer: Damn it, Neil. The name is Nuwanda.

question: Excuse me. May we have a word, Mr. Keating?
answer: Certainly.

question: This was my first classroom, John. Did you know that? My first desk.
answer: Didn't know you taught, Mr. Nolan.

question: English. Oh, long before your time. It was hard giving it up, I can tell you. I'm hearing rumors, John, about some unorthodox teaching methods in your classroom. I'm not saying they've anything to do with the Dalton boy's outburst. But I don't think I have to warn you boys his age are very impressionable.
answer: Well, your reprimand made quite an impression, I'm sure.

question: What was going on in the courtyard the other day?
answer: Courtyard?

question: Yeah. Boys marching, clapping in unison.
answer: Oh, that. That was an exercise to prove a point. Dangers of conformity.

question: Well, John, the curriculum here is set. It's proven it works. If you question, what's to prevent them from doing the same?
answer: I always thought the idea of educating was to learn to think for yourself.

question: Creak. He started walking around towards my left. Creak. Creak. "Assume the position, Mr. Dalton."
answer: It's all right, gentlemen.

question: Mr. Keating.
answer: Mr. Dalton. That was a pretty lame stunt you pulled today.

question: You're siding with Mr. Nolan? What about Carpe diem and sucking all the marrow out of life and all that?
answer: Sucking the marrow out of life doesn't mean choking on the bone. Sure there's a time for daring and there's a time for caution, and a wise man understands which is called for.

question: But I thought you'd like that.
answer: No. You being expelled from school is not daring to me. It's stupid, 'cause you'll miss some golden opportunities.

question: Yeah. Like what?
answer: Like, if nothing else, the opportunity to attend my classes. Got it, Ace?

question: Aye, aye, Captain.
answer: Keep your head about you. That goes for the lot of you.

question: Save some for me. "But, room, Fairy! Here comes Oberon." Father.
answer: Neil.

question: Wait a minute. Before you say anything, please let me ex-
answer: Don't you dare talk back to me! It's bad enough that you've wasted your time with this, this absurd acting business. But you deliberately deceived me! How, how, how did you expect to get away with this? Answer me. Who put you up to it? Was it this new man? This, uh, Mr. Keating?

question: No. Nobody-- I thought I'd surprise you. I've gotten all A's in every class.
answer: Did you think I wasn't going to find out? "Oh, my niece is in a play with your son," says Mrs. Marks. "No, no, no," I say, "you must be mistaken. My son's not in a play." You made me a liar of me, Neil! Now, tomorrow you go to them and you tell them that you're quitting.

question: No, I can't. I have the main part. The performance is tomorrow night.
answer: I don't care if the world comes to an end tomorrow night. You are through with that play. Is that clear? Is that clear?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: I made a great many sacrifices to get you here, Neil, and you will not let me down.

question: No, sir.
answer: It's open. Neil, what's up?

question: Can I speak to you a minute?
answer: Certainly. Sit down.

question: I'm sorry. Here.
answer: Excuse me. Get you some tea?

question: Tea. Sure.
answer: Like some milk or sugar in that?

question: No, thanks. Gosh, they don't give you much room around here.
answer: No, it's part of the monastic oath. They don't want worldly things distracting me from my teaching.

question: She's pretty.
answer: She's also in London. Makes it a little difficult.

question: How can you stand it?
answer: Stand what?

question: You can go anywhere. You can do anything. How can you stand being here?
answer: 'Cause I love teaching. I don't wanna be anywhere else. What's up?

question: I just talked to my father. He's making me quit the play at Henley Hall. Acting's everything to me. I-- But he doesn't know. He-- I can see his point. We're not a rich family like Charlie's, and we-- But he's planning the rest of my life for me, and I-- H-He's never asked me what I want.
answer: Have you ever told your father what you just told me? About your passion for acting. You ever show him that?

question: I can't.
answer: Why not?

question: I can't talk to him this way.
answer: Then you're acting for him, too. You're playing the part of the dutiful son. I know this sounds impossible, but you have to talk to him. You have to show him who you are, what your heart is.

question: I know what he'll say. He'll tell me that acting's a whim, and I should forget it. That how they're counting on me. He'll just tell me to put it out of my mind, "for my own good."
answer: You are not an indentured servant. If it's not a whim for you, you prove it to him by your conviction and your passion. You show him that And if he still doesn't believe you, well, by then you'll be out of school and you can do anything you want.

question: No. What about the play? The show's tomorrow night.
answer: Well, you have to talk to him before tomorrow night.

question: Isn't there an easier way?
answer: No.

question: I'm trapped.
answer: No, you're not.

question: Chris! Chris Noel. Do you know where she is? Thanks. Excuse me. Chris.
answer: Knox, what are you doing here?

question: I came to apologize for the other night. I brought you these and a poem I wrote for you.
answer: Knox, don't you know that, if Chet finds you here he'll kill you?

question: I can't care. I love you, Chris.
answer: Knox, you're crazy.

question: Look, I acted like a jerk and I know it. Please, accept these. Please.
answer: No. No-- I, I can't. Forget it. Knox, I don't believe this.

question: Chris, you can't be in here. I-If they catch you, we're both gonna be in big trouble.
answer: Oh, but it's fine-- It's fine for you to come barging into my school and make a complete fool out of me?

question: I didn't mean to make a fool out of you.
answer: Well, you did. Chet found out. And it took everything I could do to keep him from coming here and killing you. Knox, you have got to stop this stuff.

question: I can't, Chris. I love you.
answer: Knox, you say that over and over. You don't, you don't even know me.

question: Go ahead, Captain. I'll walk.
answer: Knox, Knox, it just so happens that I could care less about you?

question: Then you wouldn't be here warning me about Chet.
answer: I have to go. I'm gonna be late for the play.

question: Are you going with him?
answer: Chet? To a play? Are you kidding?

question: Then come with me.
answer: Knox, you are so infuriating.

question: Come on, Chris. Just give me one chance. If you don't like me after tonight, I'll stay away forever.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I promise. Dead Poets Honor. You come with me tonight. And then, if you don't want to see me again, I swear I'll bow out.
answer: You know what would happen if Chet found out?

question: He won't know anything. We'll sit in the back and sneak away as soon as it's over.
answer: And I suppose you would promise that this would be the end of it.

question: Dead Poets Honor.
answer: What is that?

question: My word.
answer: You are so infuriating.

question: Go on, get some sleep.
answer: It's all right. It's going to be all right. What was that?

question: What?
answer: That sound.

question: What sound? Tom? What is it? What's wrong?
answer: Neil.

question: Tom, what is it? What's wrong? Neil?
answer: Neil?

question: I'll look outside. Neil?
answer: No! Oh, Neil! Oh, my God!

question: Oh! No!
answer: Oh, my son!

question: He's all right.
answer: My son! My poor son!

question: He's all right! He's all right! He's all right! He's all right! He's all right! He's all right!
answer: Stop it! Stop it! Stop it.

question: Todd? Todd.
answer: Oh, Charlie. What is it?

question: Neil's dead.
answer: It's so beautiful.

question: Todd. It's okay, Todd.
answer: Calm down.

question: It's all right, Todd.
answer: Todd, it's okay. It's okay, Todd.

question: It was his father!
answer: No!

question: He wouldn't have left us. It's because he- He wouldn't have. His dad was-- his, his father did it.
answer: Todd.

question: You told him about this meeting?
answer: Twice.

question: That's it, guys. We're all fried.
answer: How do you mean?

question: Cameron's a fink. He's in Nolan's office right now, finking.
answer: About what?

question: The club, Pittsie. Think about it. The board of directors, the trustees and Mr. Nolan. Do you think for one moment they're gonna let this thing just blow over? Schools go down because of things like this. They need a scapegoat.
answer: What's going on, guys?

question: You finked, didn't you, Cameron?
answer: Finked? I didn't know what the hell you're talking about.

question: You told Nolan everything about the club is what I'm talking about.
answer: Look, in case you hadn't heard, Dalton, there's something called an honor code at this school, all right? If a teacher asks you a question, you tell the truth or you're expelled.

question: He's right there, Charlie. And if you guys are smart, you will do exactly what I did and cooperate. They're not after us. We're the victims. Us and Neil.
answer: What's that mean? Who are they after?

question: Why, Mr. Keating, of course. The "Captain" himself. I mean, you guys didn't really think he could avoid responsibility, did you?
answer: Mr. Keating responsible for Neil? Is that what they're saying?

question: Meeks?
answer: Go away. I have to study.

question: What happened to Nuwanda?
answer: Expelled.

question: What'd you tell 'em?
answer: Nothing they didn't already know.

question: Mom.
answer: Have a seat, Mr. Anderson. Mr. Anderson, I think we've pretty well put together what's happened here. You do admit to being a part of this Dead Poets Society?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: I have here a detailed description of what occurred at your meetings. It describes how your teacher, Mr. Keating, encouraged you boys to organize this club and to use it as a source of inspiration for reckless and self- indulgent behavior. It describes how Mr. Keating, both in and out of the classroom, encouraged Neil Perry to follow his obsession with acting when he knew all along it was against the explicit order of Neil's parents. It was Mr. Keating's blatant abuse of his position as teacher that led directly to Neil Perry's death. Read that document carefully, Todd. Very carefully. If you've nothing to add or amend, sign it.

question: Sit. I'll be teaching this class through exams. We'll find a permanent English teacher during the break. Who will tell me where you are in the Pritchard textbook? Mr. Anderson?
answer: Uh, in the, in the Pr-

question: I can't hear you, Mr. Anderson.
answer: In the, in the, in the Pritchard?

question: Kindly inform me, Mr. Cameron.
answer: We skipped around a lot, sir. We covered the Romantics and some of the chapters on Post Civil War literature.

question: What about the Realists?
answer: I believe we skipped most of that, sir.

question: Get them now, Mr. Keating. Gentlemen, turn to page 21 of the introduction. Mr. Cameron, read aloud the excellent essay by Dr. Pritchard on "Understanding Poetry."
answer: That page has been ripped out, sir.

question: Well, borrow somebody else's book.
answer: They're all ripped out, sir.

question: What do you mean, they're all ripped out?
answer: Sir, we, uh-

question: Never mind. Read!
answer: "Understanding Poetry by Dr. J Evans Pritchard, Ph.D. To fully understand poetry, we must first be fluent with its meter, rhyme and figures of speech, then ask two questions "... How important is that objective? Question 1 rates the poem's perfection; question 2 rates its importance. And once these questions have been answered, determining the poem's greatness becomes a relatively simple matter. If the poem's score for perfection is plotted on the horizontal of a graph--"

question: Leave, Mr. Keating.
answer: But it wasn't his fault!

question: Sit down, Mr. Anderson! One more outburst from you or anyone else, and you're out of this school! Leave, Mr. Keating. I said leave, Mr. Keating.
answer: O Captain! My Captain!
